------=_NextPart_000_0A38_01CB26A9.FE375A00
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Colin,
 
When adding or splitting either connections or nodes, and especially when
these new features improve function, I wonder about what precisely the
meaning of that function is.  If it is a component of computation, for
example, what role does it play?
 
These become patterns that represent some underlying functionality, often
underdetermined (and then you have to do some addtional pattern matching to
try and see what they mean). In other words, these constructs are not just
nodes and connections.
 
Do you see what I'm getting at?
 
Ken Lloyd

  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Sunday, July 18, 2010 4:01 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Node-split mutation


  

The standard NEAT approach for adding nodes is to split a connection, e.g.

1------>2
Split connection to give
1---->3---->2

I was wondering if splitting nodes would have additional worth. E.g.

(1,2,3) ---> 4 ---> (5,6,7)
Split 4 to give:
(1,2,3) ---> 4 ---> 8 ---> (5,6,7)

So 4 became 4 and 8 with a connection between them. One notable change
this allows is for lots of connections coming into an output node to
be split away into a hidden node adjacent to the output.

(1,2,3) ---> out
Split output node:
(1,2,3) ---> 4 ---> out

Same for an input:
in ----> (1,2,3)
Split input node:
in ---> 4 ---> (1,2,3)

Any thoughts?

Colin.
